# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

None.

Here is the Julia code that solves your problem:
```julia
function wrap_string(s::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " " * word) > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = ""
        end
        line *= word * " "
    end
    return result * line # append the remaining line to the result
end

# Example usage:
s = "This is a test string. It will be broken up into multiple lines if necessary."
println(wrap_string(s))
```
In this function, we split the input string into words and then add each word to a new line only when it would exceed the maximum `text_width`. The function handles strings with spaces between words correctly. It also adds an extra newline at the end of the result to separate the final line from other output.

Please note that this code assumes that you want to split your string by spaces and that a word is any sequence of characters separated by spaces, so punctuation marks will be treated as part of the preceding word. If you have different requirements, you may need to modify this function accordingly.
